text.headline: Planck's Quantum Hypothesis
text.text: Max Planck introduces the idea that energy is emitted or absorbed in discrete packets called quanta, solving the black-body radiation problem.

text.headline: Einstein and the Photoelectric Effect
text.text: Albert Einstein explains the photoelectric effect by postulating that light consists of particles called photons, building on Planck's work.

text.headline: Bohr Model of the Atom
text.text: Niels Bohr proposes a model where electrons orbit the nucleus in specific energy levels, explaining atomic spectra.

text.headline: Schrödinger Equation
text.text: Erwin Schrödinger develops the wave equation that describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes over time.

text.headline: Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle
text.text: Werner Heisenberg states that it is impossible to simultaneously know precisely both the position and momentum of a particle.

text.headline: Nuclear Fission Discovered
text.text: Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann discover nuclear fission, the process by which an atom's nucleus splits into smaller parts.

text.headline: First Self-Sustaining Nuclear Chain Reaction
text.text: Enrico Fermi leads the team achieving the first self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction at the University of Chicago.

text.headline: Atomic Bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki
text.text: The first and only use of atomic weapons in warfare occurs, demonstrating the destructive power of nuclear fission.

text.headline: First Nuclear Power Plant
text.text: The Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant in the Soviet Union becomes the world's first nuclear power plant to generate electricity for a power grid.

text.headline: First Working Laser
text.text: Theodore Maiman invents the first working laser, a device that amplifies light by stimulated emission of radiation.

text.headline: Quantum Computing Concepts Emerge
text.text: Paul Benioff introduces the concept of a quantum mechanical model of a Turing machine.

text.headline: Shor's Algorithm for Quantum Computers
text.text: Peter Shor develops an algorithm that allows a quantum computer to factor large integers much faster than any known classical algorithm, posing a threat to current encryption methods.

text.headline: First NMR Quantum Computer
text.text: Researchers build the first 5-qubit NMR quantum computer.

text.headline: Quantum Supremacy Claim
text.text: Google's Sycamore processor reportedly performs a computation in 200 seconds that would take the fastest supercomputer 10,000 years, achieving 'quantum supremacy'.
